title: Learning as a Team
content: Team learning requires deliberate practices: debriefs, after-action reviews, shared reflection. Learning must be explicitâ€”assuming the team absorbed lessons from experience overestimates natural learning. Without structured review, teams repeat mistakes and miss improvement opportunities.

scenario.story: Two teams complete similar projects. Team A finishes and moves to the next task. Team B spends 30 minutes in debrief discussing what worked, what didn't, and what they'd do differently. Six months later, Team A repeats several mistakes from the first project. Team B has measurably improved their process.

options.A: Team A was more efficient by not spending time on review
options.B: Team B's investment in structured learning paid dividends
options.C: Some teams naturally learn without formal review
options.D: Experience is the best teacher regardless of review

scenario.explanation: Experience without reflection produces less learning than structured review. The 30-minute investment generated lasting improvements. Team A's 'efficiency' cost them repeated errors. Learning requires deliberate extraction.
